instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
Hi, I got a Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that is not booting, possible water damage but Im not sure... the connector J5110 has 3 pins burned: 18, 20, 22 the line of those pins is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3HSW_DFR</SIGNAL>, the line still has 3.3V
The board is out it consumes 20V and 0.50A in the boot process it go a high as 0.52 and the stays around .50A  CPU gets hot, board looks very clean no corrosion, shift key green light not present.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
L7220: 0.843V
L7210: 0.843V
L7420: 0V
L7410 fluctuates between 0.01 to 0.030V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL>: 1.199V
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S0SW</SIGNAL>: 1.059V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>: 1.8V

[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>IMAGE_50755585</SIGNAL>.JPG"]60812[/ATTACH]

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
CPU core should drop to 0.6V aprox, when board boots; if stuck on 0.84V no good.
Compare diode mode readings on the other J5110's lines with good board.
T2 might suffered damage on the data lines connected to touchbar.

Check if DFU revive helps.
If no important data on its SSD, go for restore.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
Thank you for your reply.
at the beginning very fast to 0.5*V then to 0.84V and stays there...
on a good board J5110 line diode mode: 0.551
bad board: 0.539

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
Do you get 0.551 on all J5110 lines?
No big difference between 0.551 to 0.539; there must be other problem.
Compare voltage on all pins.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
What about DFU?
Did you replace J5110?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message: DFU didnt work, I did a restore it went thru and appeared a lockpad icon but still no boot, no green light on shift key, cpu still gets warm...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
Still not sure if you've replaced J5110.

Test the board alone on the desk, nothing connected, apart of charger.
Just check the CPU core voltage.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message:
j5110 not replaced, but is not doing short or anything as the pinÂ´s readings are all good. not easy to find that connector.
will check CPu voltage

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message: CPU voltages the same 0.844V but now the amperage increased to 0.60-0.64A before DFU was around 0.50-0.52A

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message: At least remove J5110 and test again.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A wont boot
threads.message: Possibly bad CPU, or some damage caused to T2.
